questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for the following device?
questions.solution:
The device shown is a tracheostomy tube. This is a tube that is inserted through the neck into the trachea to provide an airway. It is used for patients with acute upper airway obstruction, prolonged mechanical ventilation, and other conditions.

Other options :

  • Pulmonary toilet: Pulmonary toilet is the process of clearing mucus and other secretions from the lungs. It is important for patients with respiratory problems, such as COPD or cystic fibrosis.
  • Upper airway assessment: Upper airway assessment is the process of evaluating the upper airway for abnormalities. It is often performed in patients with sleep apnea or other breathing problems.
  • Prolonged mechanical ventilation: Tracheostomy tubes are commonly used in patients who require prolonged mechanical ventilation to facilitate long-term airway management and weaning from the ventilator.

questions.text: Steeple sign on X-ray neck AP view is seen in?
questions.solution:
The "steeple sign" on an X-ray of the neck (AP view) is indicative of acute laryngotracheobronchitis, commonly known as croup. Croup is characterized by inflammation of the upper airway, specifically the larynx and trachea, leading to narrowing of the subglottic region and causing the characteristic steeple-like appearance on X-ray.

Other options:

A. Acute epiglottitis: Acute epiglottitis causes inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis, which leads to a "thumbprint sign" on X-ray, not the steeple sign.

C. Laryngomalacia: Laryngomalacia is a congenital condition where the soft tissues of the larynx collapse during inspiration, causing a characteristic "omega-shaped" epiglottis on X-ray, not the steeple sign.

D. Laryngeal web: A laryngeal web is a congenital condition where there is a membrane or web-like structure across the larynx, which may cause respiratory difficulty, but it does not result in the steeple sign on X-ray.

questions.text: Name the maneuver shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Epley's maneuver

The image shows the Epley maneuver, which is a therapeutic maneuver used to treat benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The Epley maneuver involves a series of head and body movements to reposition the displaced calcium crystals (otoconia) within the inner ear.

Other options:

A. Brandt-Daroff maneuver - The Brandt-Daroff maneuver is another therapeutic exercise used to treat BPPV. It involves sitting on the edge of a bed and performing a specific set of movements to reposition the otoconia.

C. Foster maneuver - The Foster maneuver is used for self-administration of canalith repositioning for BPPV involving the posterior semicircular canal.

D. Semont maneuver - The Semont maneuver is another canalith repositioning maneuver used to treat BPPV.

questions.text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below:
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option B: Laryngeal papilloma: Usually it is a single in size, less aggressive and doesnot recur after surgical removal. It is common in the age group of 30-5-yrs and usualy arises from the anterior half of the vocal cord or the anterior commissure as in the above image.

Option A: Reinke's oedema: it occurs due to collection of the oedema fluid in the sub-epithelial space of reinke, usual cause is vocal abuse and smoking. Both the vocal cords show diffuse symmetrical swelling.

Option C: Malignancy: Malignant lesions of the vocal cord may appear as irregular masses or ulcerations but usually don't present as exophytic lesions.

Option D: Tracheomalacia: It refers to the weekening of the tracheal cartilage which may cause the tracheal collapse during respiration and is not evident in the above image.

questions.text: Tubercular otitis media is characterized by all except
questions.solution:
Tubercular otitis media is characterized by multiple perforations in the tympanic membrane, pale granulations, and foul-smelling ear discharge. Painful otorrhea is not a typical feature of tubercular otitis media.

Other options and why they are wrong:

B. Multiple perforations: Multiple perforations in the tympanic membrane are a characteristic feature of tubercular otitis media due to the destructive nature of the disease.

C. Pale granulations: Tubercular otitis media is associated with pale or edematous granulations due to the chronic inflammatory process.

D. Foul-smelling ear discharge: Foul-smelling or purulent ear discharge is commonly observed in tubercular otitis media due to the chronic infection.

questions.text: All of the following are smell perception tests except?
questions.solution:
D. Arnold stick test

The Arnold's nerve ear-cough reflex test, also known as the Arnold stick test, is a neurological examination that uses a cotton swab on a stick to trigger a cough

The test can help diagnose neurological conditions. It's an example of hypersensitivity of the vagal afferent nerves, which can be a sign of a sensory neuropathy of the vagus nerve

A. Smell diskettes

Smell diskettes are small, disposable disks that contain a variety of different odors.

The patient is asked to smell the diskettes and identify the odors. This test is a measure of the patient's ability to smell.

B. UP-SIT

UP-SIT stands for Upper Airway Resistance Sensitivity Index Test. This test is used to assess the resistance of the upper airway to airflow.

The test is performed by measuring the pressure drop across the upper airway when the patient breathes in and out.

C. CC-SIT

CC-SIT stands for Conductance Change Sensitivity Index Test. This test is also used to assess the resistance of the upper airway to airflow.

The test is performed by measuring the change in conductance of the upper airway when the patient breathes in and out.

questions.text: What is the structure being shown with the arrow in the given CT SCAN image?
questions.solution:
The structure shown with the arrow in the CT scan image is: Onodi cell

The Onodi cell, also known as the sphenoethmoidal cell, is a type of paranasal sinus cell that is located posteriorly and superiorly to the sphenoid sinus. It is located just above the sphenoid sinus and can be closely related to important structures such as the optic nerve and carotid artery.

B. Agger nasi: The agger nasi cell is located anteriorly to the ethmoid sinus, near the frontal recess, and is not represented by the arrow in the image.

C. Concha bullosa: Concha bullosa is a pneumatized middle turbinate, and it is not the structure shown in the image.

D. Haller cell: Haller cell is an infraorbital ethmoid air cell and is not represented by the arrow in the image.

questions.text: Which is the most common source of bleeding during tonsillectomy?
questions.solution:
A. Paratonsillar vein: After tonsillectomy (tonsil surgery), postoperative bleeding can occur, and the bleeding source is commonly the paratonsillar vein (peritonsillar vein). The paratonsillar vein is located near the tonsils and can be a site of bleeding following tonsil surgery. Post-tonsillectomy hemorrhage is a known complication, and the bleeding often originates from this vein.

B. External palatine vein: This is a less likely source of bleeding because it is located further away from the tonsils.

C. Ascending pharyngeal artery: This is less likely to cause bleeding because it is located further away from the tonsils and is a larger vessel.

D. Facial artery: This is less likely to cause bleeding because it is located further away from the tonsils and is a larger vessel.

questions.text: Given below is the image of a patient who underwent laryngectomy. Which mode of speech is he using?
questions.solution: In the image, a laryngectomy has been performed, which means the patient's larynx (voice box) has been removed. In such cases, patients often use alternative methods to produce speech. Tracheoesophageal speech is a common method used by laryngectomy patients. It involves the surgical creation of a small opening between the trachea and the esophagus, through which air can be redirected from the lungs into the esophagus. By expelling air from the esophagus, patients can produce speech sounds and communicate.

questions.text: Identify the nerve block in the following figure:
questions.solution:
The nerve block shown in the picture above is to block nasociliary nerve.

To block the nasociliary nerve, or it's branches, 3cm, 25 G needle is inserted 1 cm above inner canthus and directed posterolaterally keeping contact with bone.

questions.text: Which of the following airway obstruction level causes inspiratory stridor?
questions.solution: Stridor means noisy breathing. It is due to airway obstruction. Depending on the level of obstruction, it is of three types.

choices.text: Sub glottis is the narrowest part of infant larynx
Cricothyroid muscle is supplied by recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about anatomy of larynx-
questions.solution: Cricothyroid muscle is supplied by external branch of superior laryngeal nerve. Rest all laryngeal muscles which move the vocal cord are supplied by recurrent laryngeal nerve.

questions.text: Montgomery's silicon T - tube is used in which of the following surgical procedure?
questions.solution: Montgomery's silicon T tube is used for laryngotracheal reconstruction in congenital subglottic stenosis. This tube is used to support the reconstructed segment for 6 weeks.

choices.text: Uses flashing light passed via flexible or rigid endoscope
Flashes of light are synchronised to vocal cord vibration
Does not assess the mucosal wave form of vocal cord on phonation
A very useful investigation in patients of voice disorders

questions.text: Which of the following is not applicable to Videostroboscopy of larynx?
questions.solution:
Videostroboscopy helps to assess the mucosal wave form of vocal cord on phonation

VF - vocal fold

questions.text: General contraindications for partial laryngectomies includes all except :
questions.solution:
Partial laryngectomy is done for T2 carcinoma larynx.

Supraglottic extension is not a contraindication for partial laryngectomy.

Fixed cords-implies stage T3

Cartilage invasion, significant oropharyngeal extension- stage T4a

questions.text: Which of the following describes Type II cordectomy correctly
questions.solution:
Subligamental cordectomy - Type II cordectomy

  • Resection of the epithelium, Reinke's space and the vocal ligament
  • For glottic carcinoma

questions.text: All of the following are helpful in the treatment of obstructive sleep apnea except -
questions.solution:
Muller's manoeuvre -

  • An endoscope is used to look for collapse of soft tissues in the oropharynx when the patient inspires vigorously.
  • Level of pharyngeal obstruction can be found.
  • It plays a role in the diagnosis of obstructive sleep apnea but has no role in its treatment.

Treatment options for OSA include -

A. Lifestyle changes

  • Weight loss
  • Quit alcohol and smoking
  • Dietary modification

B. Positional therapy-Sleeping on the side as supine position may cause OSA.

C. CPAP(Continuous Positive Airway Pressure)or BiPAP(bilevel positive airway pressure) when CPAP is not tolerated. These devices maintain a positive pressure and keep the airway open.

D. Surgical-Laser Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty(UPPP) - The aim is to increase the size of airway.

questions.text: All of these constitute the Waldeyer's ring except
questions.solution:
Submental lymph nodes are not a part of Waldeyer's ring.

Scattered throughout the pharynx in its subepithelial layer is the lymphoid tissue which is aggregated at places to form masses, collectively called Waldeyer's ring.

Includes -

  • Nasopharyngeal tonsil or the adenoid
  • Palatine tonsils
  • Lingual tonsil
  • Tubal tonsils
  • Lateral pharyngeal bands
  • Nodules(in posterior pharyngeal wall).

questions.text: All of the following are used for tonsillectomy except:
questions.solution:
Suction diathermy is a method of adenoidectomy.

Others are methods of tonsillectomy.

choices.text: Cellulitis of floor of the mouth
Aphthous ulcers in the floor of Mouth

questions.text: 'Ludwig's angina' is characterized by all the following EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Aphthous ulcers are recurrent and superficial, usually involving movable mucosa, i.e., inner surfaces of lips, buccal mucosa, tongue, floor of mouth and soft palate, while sparing mucosa of the hard palate and gingivae.

Ludwig's Angina:

  • Infection of submandibular space(sublingual space + submaxillary spaces) or floor of mouth. It is mainly Cellulitis.
  • Dental Infections account for 80% of the cases. Roots of premolars cause sublingual space infection while roots of the molar teeth cause submaxillary space infection
  • Mixed infections involving aerobes and anaerobes is seen.

questions.text:
Deformities occurring in leprosy patients are:
a.tFacies leonina
b.tLow set ears
c.tSaddle nose
d.tLagophthalmos
e. Micrognathia
questions.solution:
Low set ears and micrognathia are not seen in leprosy patients.

The deformities occurring in leprosy patients are -

  • Facies Leonia
  • Saddle nose - due to depression of bridge of nose
  • Lagopthalmos - due to facial nerve involvement

questions.text: Treatment of choice for the polyp shown in the CT scan is?
questions.solution:
The CT scan shows a homogenous mass in one maxillary sinus and ipsilateral nasal cavity. So antrochoanal polyp (Killian’s polyp) is the most likely diagnosis.

The treatment of choice for antrochoanal polyp is FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery). If unavailable, endoscopic polypectomy can be done.

Intranasal polypectomy and Caldwell Luc operations were done previously for antrochoanal polyp.

Intranasal ethmoidectomy was done previously for ethmoidal polyp.

All these are superseded by endoscopic surgeries now.

questions.text: Lautenschlaeger's operation is indicated for?
questions.solution:
Atrophic rhinitis can be managed medically and surgically.

SURGICAL MANAGEMENT INCLUDES -

  • Young's operation→ Complete closure of both nostrils. They are opened after 6 months.
  • Modified Young's operation→ Partial closure of nostrils leaving behind a 3mm hole.
  • Lautenschlaeger technique→ Narrowing of nasal cavities by medial displacement of lateral wall of nose

choices.text: Arises from upper part of nasal septum

questions.text: All statements are true about Ringertz tumour of Nose except
questions.solution:
Ringertz tumor arises from lateral wall of nose.

Inverted Papilloma (Transitional Cell Papilloma or Ringertz Tumour or Schneiderian Papilloma)

  • It is a tumour of the non-olfactory mucosa of nose (Schneiderian membrane) and paranasal sinuses.
  • Most common site of origin is lateral wall of nose in the middle meatus
  • It is a benign but locally invasive tumour and can show malignant conversion.
  • Human papilloma virus is thought to be responsible for its aetiology.
  • Clinically, men are affected more than women in the age group of 40–70.
  • Treatment - Medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice. These days endoscopic approach is preferred.
  • Radiotherapy is not advised as it may induce malignancy.

questions.text: Facies leprosa is characterised by all except:
questions.solution:
Nodules on face are not a feature of facies leprosa.

Facies leprosa -

  • Seen in lepromatous leprosy
  • Characterized by the resorption of the nasal bone, anterior nasal spine, supra-incisive alveolar region, and anterior alveolar process of the maxilla, with associated sensory or motor damage depending on the type of nerves involved.

choices.text: Sensorineural deafness is a common feature
Red bulging tympanic membrane is a common otoscopic finding
Tympanostomy tubes are usually required for treatment
Ear ache is a common symptom

questions.text: In the given condition, which one of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
The given condition is GLUE EAR (OTITIS MEDIA WITH EFFUSION-OME)

Option A : CHL is seen not SNHL.

Option B : On Examination:

  • Glue like fluid behind TM.
  • Air bubbles trapped within glue.
  • Retracted tympanic membrane.
  • Very rarely bluish tympanic membrane.

Option C : Correct

Option D : Ear ache is not common symptom often we see heaviness in the ear.

questions.text: The most common site of cholesteatoma in the middle ear cleft is
questions.solution: Prussak's space is the most common site of cholesteatoma formation in middle ear. It lies between the pars flaccida and the neck of malleus.

choices.text: Outer hair cells are more in number as compared to inner hair cells
Outer hair cells are more vulnerable to noise and drugs
Outer hair cells mainly transmit the auditory stimuli
Inner hair cells are flask shaped and outer hair cells are cylindrical

questions.text: Not true about organ of corti hair cells
questions.solution: Outer hair cells modulate function of inner hair cells.

questions.text: Which is the diagnostic investigation of choice in assessing hearing loss in children?
questions.solution:
BERA (brainstem evoked response audiometry) is to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain. In this method, electrical potentials are generated in response to several click stimuli or tone bursts and picked up from the vertex by surface electrodes. It measures hearing sensitivity in the range of 1000-4000 Hz. ABR is used:

  1. As a screening procedure for infants.
  2. To determine the threshold of hearing in infants; also in children and adults who do not cooperate and in malingerers.
  3. To diagnose retrocochlear pathology particularly acoustic neuroma.
  4. To diagnose brainstem pathology, e.g. multiple sclerosis or pontine tumours.
  5. To monitor CN VIII intraoperatively in surgery of acoustic neuromas to preserve the function of cochlear nerve.

questions.text:
A patient with recurrent episodes of facial paralysis has following findings on examination of oral cavity


What is the name of this entity?
questions.solution:
Melkersson Rosenthal Syndrome Consists of Triad of

  • Recurrent facial paralysis
  • Swelling of lips
  • Fissured tongue
